page.title: 01North Bute
page.content: Although containing the small village of Colintraive Habitation occurs only two of the twele KM squares in this block. Whilst some of th lower land near the sea is used for grazing the majority of the area, between 50m and 195m, is wet moorland. Dalradian schists and grits, frequently exposed, underly the moorland which consits of rough grassland, bracken, heather, bogs, mosses, and some deciduous woodland. The colintraive-Rhubodach ferry is the shortest crossing from the mainland and a year round service operates but this by no means matches the Rothesay-Wemyss Bay service in terms of traffice due to the latter's superior connections on the mainland. Apart from one farm, the north end of Bute is uninhabited although home to much wildlife including deer and visiting seals. the Kyles of bute
